node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text: For most of 2020 the theory that covid-19 leaked from a Chinese lab was dismissed as unlikely. In the past few months it has gained currency. Our experts explain why. Cover credit: Getty Images

node.text: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies set out to upend the financial order and replace conventional money. Bitcoin has certainly disrupted the global financial system, but can it ever live up to the hype? Cover credit: Jakub Porzycki/Getty Images

node.title: Crypto: will the bitcoin dream succeed?

node.text:
Jair Bolsonaro’s actions do not just threaten Brazilian democracy—they have also endangered one of the world’s most important natural resources. 

So why are the right-wing president’s followers still so faithful?

Cover image: Fernando Bizerra Jr/EPA-EFE-Shutterstock

node.text:
Trophy hunting sparks outrage around the world. But the highly controversial sport can actually help to protect some of Africa's most endangered big animals. Here's how.

Credit: Alamy

node.title: How trophy hunting can protect Africa's wildlife

node.text:
In America, black people are almost twice more likely to die from covid-19 as white people. Our journalists explain how the pandemic has illuminated systemic racism in America. 

Cover image credit: Getty Images

node.title: How covid-19 exposes systemic racism in America

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 15, 2021. node.text:
⁠The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has released a report on the physical science of climate change.⁠
⁠
While carbon dioxide remains at the heart of the climate problem, the report makes clear that methane should be looked at more seriously too when tackling global warming.⁠
⁠
Methane is a more powerful greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide, but it only lasts in the atmosphere for about a decade. ⁠
⁠
This means by reducing methane emissions we can make progress faster. If we don't, stopping climate change will be harder.⁠
⁠
So how could humans make radical cuts to methane levels? Click the link in our bio to find out. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @kaltoons1

node.text:
For decades, China's growth was turbocharged—then it slowed down. ⁠
⁠
From 1980 to 2010 the country's annual GDP growth averaged 10%. But the central bank now thinks potential growth is about 5.5% a year.⁠
⁠
China’s future economic potential also hinges on its productivity. ⁠
⁠
Since 2008, China's total-factor productivity has grown by just 1.1% per year, less than a third of the rate of the previous three decades.⁠
⁠
The government has a (32-point) plan to turn things around. ⁠
⁠
But will its policies actually work? To read why achieving Xi Jinping's aim of a high-productivity future for China may take more change than officials can stomach, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @stephaniefscholz

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 14, 2021. May be an image of ‎3 people and ‎text that says '‎German election 2021 Angela Merkel's successor could be left, right or Green حب‎'‎‎.

node.text:
The race to replace Angela Merkel is on—and Germany’s election campaign has got interesting.⁠
⁠
With a month and a half to go, the outcome is highly uncertain.⁠
⁠
Since 2005 the number of undecided voters has increased drastically. The last weeks of election campaigns have become more important than ever.⁠
⁠
With new candidates for the chancellorship, will old loyalties still hold?⁠
⁠
Our new election model crunches the latest data to come up with the most reliable estimate at how many votes and seats each party might win. ⁠
⁠
To find out what the latest projections reveal, and to learn more about the candidates hoping to succeed Ms Merkel, click on the link in our bio. #BTW21⁠
⁠
Illustration: @elliefp

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'DUNGEONS AND DIMPLES: HOW TO SPEAK K-PoP'.

node.text:
Kim Jong Un reckons K-pop is a “vicious cancer”. ⁠
⁠
This scourge, said the leader of North Korea in June, is corrupting his people, influencing everything from their hairstyles to the way they speak. It is smuggled into the country on flash drives; those found with it can be sent to a labour camp for 15 years. ⁠
⁠
Mr Kim might not be a lover of South Korea’s most influential cultural export, but K-pop fervour looks like it’s here to stay.⁠
⁠
It isn’t just a blend of flawless dance routines and catchy melodies sung by immaculately coiffed, clear-skinned youths in co-ordinating outfits. K-pop has its own intricate lexicon.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio and learn how to tell your “Koreaboos” from your “sasaengs” in @1843mag’s guide to K-pop slang. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: Julia Geiser

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 14, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person, indoor and brick wall.

node.text:
⁠When Hunter S. Thompson left Los Angeles for Las Vegas in 1971, in the company of Oscar Acosta, a Mexican-American lawyer and Chicano activist, he did not mean to write a cult novel.⁠
⁠
Mr Thompson was working on a piece about Ruben Salazar, a Mexican-American journalist killed the previous year by a tear-gas canister fired by police during a march against the Vietnam war.⁠
⁠
Mr Acosta, his main source, was worried about being seen with a white writer—but agreed to go with Mr Thompson to Las Vegas, where he was due to produce the captions for a series of photographs of the Mint 400 off-road desert race. ⁠
⁠
What arose from the trip was an elusive blend of fact and fiction, observation and exaggeration, published in two parts in Rolling Stone that autumn.⁠
⁠
“Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas: A Savage Journey to the Heart of the American Dream” turns 50 this year—and has lost none of its satirical bite. To read why it still resonates, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Brownie Harris/Corbis via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 14, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, sky and text that says 'Science technology Geoengineering is conspicuously absent from the IPCC's report'.

node.text:
In 2013, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) referred to solar geoengineering as having “the potential to substantially offset a global temperature rise”. But this year it was not mentioned. Why?⁠
⁠
A lot of climate scientists and others believe that discussion of geo-engineering might lure policymakers away from greenhouse-gas cuts while not, in the end, doing any good—and possibly dashing the whole planet on to the rocks.⁠
⁠
The body of the new report agrees, finding that research has consistently shown such methods “could offset some of the effects of increasing greenhouse gases on global and regional climate, including the carbon and water cycles”.⁠
⁠
But not discussing geoengineering as a possibility, doesn't mean it will go away. Click the link in our bio to read more. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by The Economist on August 14, 2021 tagging @yannisdavy. May be an image of 3 people.

node.text:
“My ideas are in overdrive. It’s a very good time.”⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Yannis Davy Guibinga’s photographs balance tradition and modernity.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The 26-year-old Gabonese artist’s experimentation and unorthodox creative approach has produced striking results. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe through to take a look.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
@yannisdavy’s recent works feature his favourite subject: pre-colonial African traditions and mythologies, reimagining historic African fashions with a modern twist. To learn more about photography’s rising star, click on the link in our bio.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Credit: Yannis Davy Guibinga/Doyle Wham

node.text:
Was Lionel Messi’s peak in 2009-19 the greatest ever?⁠
⁠
Although historical comparisons are tricky in football, the best available data suggest that it was.⁠
⁠
At his best, Mr Messi averaged one goal per 90 minutes. Cristiano Ronaldo, his old rival at Real Madrid, reached 0.9; greats from earlier eras were below 0.8.⁠
⁠
Yet only half of Mr Messi’s value comes from shots at goal. To read how he compares with past greats, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 14, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, military uniform and outdoors.

node.text:
⁠General Mark Milley, the chairman of America’s joint chiefs of staff, and thus the country’s top military officer, provoked a furore in June when he defended West Point’s teaching of critical race theory.⁠
⁠
Though rank can upend the racial hierarchies of civilian life, it is generally still whites who do the bossing around: just 8% of the officer corps is black, compared with 14% of the population. ⁠
⁠
Professions of race blindness—“I only see green” is a frequent refrain—are common; so too is stereotyping. Only 2% of air-force pilots are black, unchanged from 30 years ago. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read more about racial integration in the US armed forces and the changes to come in the military.⁠
⁠
Credit: John Moore/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 14, 2021. May be a cartoon of standing.

node.text:
Have you tried to book a holiday lately? A tangle of arbitrary, unpredictable rules, which are constantly changing, means foreign trips are difficult to plan and costly.⁠
⁠
The average EU member state has 330 restrictions on international travel, according to UBS, up from five in March 2020.⁠
⁠
The bad news is that overseas trips will continue to be a hassle well beyond the northern summer. ⁠
⁠
Rich countries that are trying to open up are devising systems to reduce the risks, but their rules often exclude people who live in the poorest countries.⁠
⁠
Evidence of the benefits of many travel restrictions currently in place is murky, whereas the costs are clear. ⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read why covid-19 could disrupt international travel for years to come.⁠
⁠
Credit: @markalexlong

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 13, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, child, people standing and text that says 'Asia Afghanistan's neighbours are preparing for life alongside the Taliban'.

node.text:
The Taliban have overrun about a third of Afghanistan’s 34 provincial capitals in a week. They also captured Kandahar, Afghanistan’s second-largest city, Herat, its third and Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand province. ⁠
The government in Kabul is losing control. ⁠
⁠
As the spectre looms of either a full takeover by the radical Islamist group or a descent into all-out civil war, it is dawning upon regional players that they may have to step in.⁠
⁠
But Afghanistan’s neighbours—China, Iran and Pakistan—cannot agree on what to do about it. ⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read how these countries are preparing for life alongside a Taliban-ruled state. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Jim Huylebroek/The New York Times/Eyevine

node.text:
Africa depends on jabs from abroad, but has received just 103m doses for a population of almost 1.4bn. ⁠
⁠
The WHO estimates that 90% of African countries will miss even the modest target of vaccinating 10% of their populations by September unless many more doses arrive. ⁠
⁠
Yet many of the jabs they do have are being destroyed or are due to expire before they can be administered.⁠
⁠
A narrow window in which to administer doses is particularly troublesome. Many of the problems African states face are familiar: bad roads, patches of conflict, chronic shortages of health workers and fragmented supply chains. ⁠
⁠
And click the link in our bio to read how, in some countries, rumours of rancid jabs have encouraged vaccine hesitancy even further.⁠
⁠
Credit: Getty Images
